content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

The test cases are insufficient for the reverse mode. There are no tests that show the associated letters of 7 and 8. It is not easy to connect the number -> letter scheme with a phone pad through the tests alone.
The Input/Output sections are there to describe the I/O format, not to display an example...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good combinatoric practice.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle.  Good difficulty for a clash. Reverse mode might be a little hard, but the input constraints and first 2 test cases should be enough to get most people to eventually figure it out, even if they don't know what T9 input is.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle! Perfect difficulty for a Clash, plus I've always wanted to be a phone. I do think someone with their wits about them could solve this in reverse mode, but probably there are people on this site who don't even know what T9 is, and they might have a very hard time with it. Still, I think the test cases make it possible to infer what's going on, so whether to keep it eligible for reverse mode is entirely your discretion.
Oh shoot. If I edit the problem, will it need to be approved again?
No, of course it'll remain approved.
I edited the I/O description and fixed the default solution. Should be good to go now.
